question: 1) What is a primary advantage of using MNW over WEL in groundwater modeling? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Great — MNW captures realistic well behavior including layered flow, head losses, and control limits.
error: ❌ Unlike WEL, MNW handles complex multi-node flow and constraints explicitly.

question: 2) Which factors influence the cell-to-well conductance (CWC) in a Multi-Node Well? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Conductance depends on geometric and hydraulic properties around the well.
error: ❌ CWC reflects subsurface and borehole properties, not unrelated boundary elevations.

question: 3) What happens to the Q–h behavior of an MNW when a restart threshold (Qmx) is defined? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Qmx ensures that pumping only restarts when sufficient head is restored and a minimum Q is met.
error: ❌ Qmx defines restart behavior — it does not allow flow increase while the well is inactive, and it does not create a visible step in the Q–h curve.

question: 4) In MODFLOW, which conditions may cause a MNW to stop pumping due to head constraints? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Spot on. MNW may stop pumping when physical or hydraulic head constraints are violated.
error: ❌ Shutdowns relate to local head conditions, not flux limits or recharge rates.

question: 5) How is the skin effect incorporated in MNW behavior? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Skin increases resistance and contributes to head loss.
error: ❌ Skin increases drawdown — it does not boost conductance or affect recharge.

question: 6) How can Q–h plots assist in interpreting MNW model behavior? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. Q–h plots help understand how pumping responds to drawdown, thresholds, and constraints.
error: ❌ These plots are used to diagnose well response, not to calibrate recharge boundaries.
